row.title: Breast Cancer
row.field_page_description: DCEG researchers conduct studies on breast cancer, a cancer that usually forms in the breast ducts (tubes that carry milk to the nipple) and lobules (glands that make milk). Breast cancer occurs in both men and women, although male breast cancer is rare.
row.field_feature_card_description: DCEG researchers conduct studies on breast cancer
row.field_list_description: DCEG researchers conduct studies on breast cancer, a cancer that usually forms in the breast ducts (tubes that carry milk to the nipple) and lobules (glands that make milk). Breast cancer occurs in both men and women, although male breast cancer is rare.

row.title: Lymphoma (Burkitt, Hodgkin, and non-Hodgkin)
row.field_page_description: DCEG conducts research on cancers of the white blood cells, known as lymphomas. DCEG's work includes studies of Burkitt lymphoma, Hodgkin lymphoma, and non-Hodgkin lymphoma and its subtypes.

row.field_list_description: The Cancer Genomics Research Laboratory (CGR) investigates the contribution of germline and somatic genetic variation to cancer susceptibility and outcomes in support of DCEG's research.

row.title: Laboratory of Genetic Susceptibility

row.title: Cancer Types Studied in DCEG
row.field_page_description: Cancer types studied by DCEG investigators: breast, bladder, blood cancers, bone marrow, brain, cervix, colon/rectum, endometrium, esophagus, familial cancer syndromes, gastrointestinal, head and neck, kidney, leukemia, liver, lymphoma, lung, melanoma, ovary, pancreas, prostate, stomach, thyroid, second cancers
row.field_feature_card_description: DCEG investigators conduct research on many types of cancer to better understand the underlying causes of each disease.
row.field_list_description: DCEG investigators conduct research on many types of cancer to better understand the underlying causes of each disease. In addition, they study second primary cancers among cancer survivors.

row.title: Laboratory of Translational Genomics
row.field_page_description: Overview, Laboratory of Translational Genomics, Division of Cancer Epidemiology & Genetics, NCI
row.field_feature_card_description: Overview, Laboratory of Translational Genomics, DCEG, NCI
row.field_list_description: The Laboratory of Translational Genomics (LTG) conducts studies on germline and somatic genetics of cancer, and analyses on particular regions of the genome conclusively identified in cancer-specific genome-wide association studies (GWAS) and linkage studies in high-risk families.

row.title: Radiation Epidemiology Branch

row.field_list_description: Overview of the Radiation Epidemiology Branch, Division of Cancer Epidemiology and Genetics. Includes research studies on ionizing and non-ionizing radiation, and dosimetry research.

row.title: Integrative Tumor Epidemiology Branch
row.field_page_description: Integrative Tumor Epidemiology Branch of DCEG conducts large-scale, international epidemiological research on cancer etiology and progression through integrative analyses of risk factors and tissue profiling to inform prevention and clinical strategies.
row.field_list_description: The Integrative Tumor Epidemiology Branch, Division of Cancer Epidemiology and Genetics (DCEG), conducts large-scale, international epidemiological research on cancer etiology and progression through integrative analyses of risk factors and tissue profiling to inform prevention and clinical strategies.

row.title: Infections and Immunoepidemiology Branch
row.field_page_description: The Infections and Immunoepidemiology Branch studies how immunity and inflammation relate to cancer risk.
row.field_feature_card_description: The Infections and Immunoepidemiology Branch studies how immunity and inflammation relate to cancer risk.
row.field_list_description: The research mission of the Infections and Immunoepidemiology Branch is to discover infectious causes of cancer, to elucidate the determinants of malignancy for established oncogenic infections, to uncover novel infection-cancer associations, and to clarify how alterations in immunity and inflammation relate to cancer risk.
